subtitle: The inaugural issue of the New Thinking Allowed
magazine was just released on March 1st.
You can download a free PDF copy from the New Thinking Allowed Foundation website.
That's newthinkingallowed.org.
You can even order a printed copy from nta-magazine.magcloud.com.
Thinking Allowed - Conversations on the leading edge of knowledge
and discovery with psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome.
I'm Jeffrey Mishlove.
Today we will be exploring the career of Edgar Cayce, the sleeping prophet.
With me is Stephen Schwartz.
Stephen is a long-time parapsychology researcher,
one of the founders of the International Remote
Viewing Association and a few other scientific organizations as well.
He is the author of The Secret Vaults of Time,
The Alexandria Project, and The Eight Laws
of Change.
Welcome, Stephen.
A pleasure.
It's a pleasure to be with you.
Yeah.
It really is.
This is the first of a series of interviews we'll be doing, and in a way we're going
to start at the beginning of your career exploring consciousness.
It seems as if invisible forces were guiding
you to connect with the Association for Research
and Enlightenment, founded by Edgar Cayce.
Well, yes, that's true.
I got into this area of research, which was not where my life was headed at all back in
the early 60s, because I had a series of highly
unusual experiences which I could not explain,
and it ended up with my going down to the ARE.
I mean...
Now, let's talk about the couple who found
you at this remote farmhouse where you lived.
I got drafted in the very early 60s.
I was working for National Geographic, and I got drafted and had to go into the army.
This was during the Vietnam period.
And I came out and through...
I wrote a movie for Colonial Williamsburg, and I sent a copy of the script to a chap
that I had met in the army who had gone to New York Film School, who was then working
for Screen Gems, and he showed it to them, and they asked me to come up to New York.
And so I was terribly excited.
I was about 22, 23 years old, and I had this
job in New York as a screenwriter, and I bought
this lovely little Mercedes 190SL convertible.
So I thought everything was just very cool.
And I got to know a lot of people.
I met Andy Warhol and Truman Capote, and I went to a party that Truman Capote gave.
And I went to the bathroom, and as I was coming
back down the hall, I looked in a mirror.
There was this antique Italian gilt mirror on the wall, and suddenly, spontaneously,
looking at myself in the mirror, I said, you are becoming an unattractive person.
You're getting caught up in a materialistic lifestyle.
Oh, completely.
Yeah.
And I said it to myself, and I thought, my God, that's right.
Something is wrong.
And I couldn't figure out what it was, because
I was doing all the things you were supposed
to do.
I was being successful at it, you know, I
mean, I was making money, and I knew all these
famous people.
Right.
Unusual for a person so young.
Yeah.
And so I left the party.
It was on Fire Island.
And I walked down, and slept on the beach, and got up the next morning, and got in my
little car, and drove back to my family's farm in Virginia, which is very rural, part
of Tidewater, Virginia, Gloucester County.
And I was in an existential crisis, because
all of the things that I thought were important
and my views about the world, all suddenly
were called into question, and I didn't know
what to replace it with.
I didn't have anything.
All the things that I, you know, the culture
tells you is what you should be doing.
I was doing, and it wasn't working.
I wasn't satisfied.
It's fair to say you didn't really, at that
point in your life, have a spiritual foundation.
None whatever.
I grew up in, and actually quite thankful to my parents, in an utterly non-religious
family.
It wasn't that they were against religion, they just weren't interested in it.
And so I had absolutely no religious background at all, in anything.
And I was sitting on the porch of this, of my family's house.
This was an old land-grant house from Colonial
Virginia, way down a school bus road, 10 miles,
and our lane was a mile long, and so it's not an easy place to get to.
And I was sitting there, really, completely in despair.
And I looked up, and walking in my mother's gardens was this middle-aged couple.
And he was dressed in a beautiful, bespoke, double-breasted gray suit, and she had on
this lovely linen dress.
They looked like people that should be in Manhattan on Park Avenue, not people that
were out in the country in Virginia.
And I looked over where the cars parked, no car.
I looked down at the water and we had a dock, no boat.
How did they get here?
I mean, who are these people?
Where did they come from?
And they saw me looking at them, and they came over and came up to the porch.
It was a big, long, green porch, looking out over the water.
And I opened the door, and they came in, and
this woman looked at me for a long beat and
said, do you believe in reincarnation?
The first word is out of her mouth.
And not, hello, is it her introduction, or, you know, do you believe in reincarnation?
I was just dumbfounded, and I thought about it for a second or for a little while.
And I said, well, I think I probably do.
It seems very symmetrical.
And she said, would you like to meet Thomas Jefferson?
And I had gone to University of Virginia, which he founded, Mr. Jefferson founded.
And I said, well, is he back?
And she said, yeah.
And then I wait.
I said, wait, wait, wait, wait, wait, wait, wait.
Who are you, and how did you get here?
Because they didn't look like crazy people at all.
So they introduced themselves as Ed and Paula Fitzgerald.
And I looked at this guy, and he looked kind of familiar.
And I realized that I had seen him at a film conference in New York.
And I said to him, are you Ed Fitzgerald, the production designer?
Did you just do Magnificent Seven?
And he said, yes.
So that gave them a kind of gravitas that made everything that was beginning to seem
very crazy a little less crazy.
And she said to me, I said, how did you get here?
Why are you here?
And she said, I had a dream that told me to come up.
And I said, yeah, well, yeah, you had a dream.
But I mean, this is not an easy place to get to.
How did you know where to turn?
And she said, well, when I woke up, I just wrote all the turns down, and I could see
the things in my mind.
And we just drove it.
We're here.
Amazing that she trusted her dreams so much.
Yeah, that she trusted her dreams.
And she said, do you know who Edgar Cayce is?
I said, no.
And she said, well, you know, he's this man
who does this psychic thing and did the same
thing.
Not far away in Virginia.
Yeah, not in Virginia Beach.
I said, well, I don't know anything about it, and I don't know anything about that.
That's the whole area.
Never had any particular interest in it.
And she said, well, I'd like to invite you down for the weekend.
And just then, this car, this green Ford station
wagon came down, and there was another young
couple in it.
And she said, give me your telephone number.
So I gave her my telephone number.
And she got in the car and drove away.
And I was left there sitting, thinking to myself, what the hell just happened?
Yeah.
I mean, it just didn't fit anything that I was familiar with.
So about a week later, I got a call, and it was a guy, and he said, this is TJ Davis,
Thomas Jefferson Davis' name, and I'd like to invite you down for the weekend.
So they gave me instructions of how to do that.
And I drove down, and I got to the address.
There was a young man up on a ladder, and
they were building some kind of leather, what
turned out to be a leather shop.
And I said, I'm looking for TJ Davis, and oh, he's not here, but Joan is.
And around the corner came this really quite
beautiful woman with these beautiful lavender
eyes.
And she said to me, oh, yes, you must be Stephen,
and I will take you up to the ARE, and I said,
what's the ARE?
Oh, that's the organization that studies Edgar Cayce.
And I thought, okay.
So I got in the car, and we drove up, and she took me into what was the old hospital
building.
Edgar Cayce had had a hospital in Virginia
Beach, and he's really the father of holistic
medicine.
And I walked into the room, and there was one whole end of it.
It was filled with these green, looked like schoolbook spiral, three-ring binders.
And she said, those are the readings, and explained to me what she thought a reading
was.
And just at random, I just was walking along,
I pulled one off a shelf and opened it up.
And it was a reading given in 1936 for a woman,
and it said that she had been a member of
the Asean community, and they gave a description
of where it was, and I recognized it as Kherbet
Qumran, and that she had been a teacher of astrology.
Because you had studied the Dead Sea Scrolls in some prior work you had done.
Yeah.
Before I went, before I got drafted, before I left to go into the Army, the last thing
I had done for the National Geographic was to
do a lot of research on the Dead Sea Scrolls
for an article that we were preparing.
And an employee at the National Geographic.
Yeah, yeah.
I was a researcher writer for Geographic.
And so I had done all this research, and it was a subject I knew about.
And I knew that in 1936, nobody knew that Kherbet Qumran was an Asean community.
It was generally thought to have been an outpost
of the Emperor of Vespasian's legions built
during the Jewish uprising.
And in general, the Aseans were thought to be a schismatic order of Jewish monks.
Josephus describes them that way.
So nobody knew women were involved, and the whole astrology thing, I mean, nobody knew
anything about that.
But then in 1947, 11 years later, a young Bedouin tribes boy had been chucking rocks
in a cave, and he struck what turned out to be
one of the urns holding the Dead Sea Scrolls.
And that's how we discovered the Dead Sea Scrolls.
And when they discovered them, they, as they
translated them and opened them up, they realized
that they were obsessed with astrology.
And when they did excavation at the site, they discovered female skeletons, so they
realized there were women present.
It wasn't just the community of male monks, as I believe Josephus had written.
Yeah, exactly.
And so they, basically, everything he said in 1936 was correct.
Many people don't, even in the parapsychology
community, don't appreciate that kind of detail
in Edgar Cayce's readings.
Well, that's true.
I mean, for cultural reasons, I think, and some historical issues, parapsychology has
never paid any attention to Edgar Cayce, which
is unfortunate, because his 15,000, not quite
And you're one of the only people who's actually read them all.
Yes.
His readings.
Yes.
And so I said to this young woman, let me take you to dinner, I have some questions,
because I was stunned.
I mean, as I read this thing, I thought, well,
this, he knew this 11 years before it was discovered
by archeology, so where was the information, and how did he access it?
I mean, where do you get information like that?
So I took her to dinner, and as we were going
through dinner, I realized that there was
something important here, and that I didn't understand it.
And some of our viewers may not know, Edgar Cayce went into a trance state.
Yes.
Okay, let me say something about that.
So I called back to the farm and said, this is
going to take a little longer than a weekend.
It actually took five years.
And the next day, I decided I would read all the readings.
You had money, you didn't have to work, you
could devote five years to an intensive study,
going through every single one of Edgar Cayce's readings.
Exactly.
And on top of that, the parapsychology library that they had.
Yes.
So I set about very systematically reading all of the readings, and I got...
In those days, the ARE was a little tiny organization of about 1,800 people.
And the people that were at Virginia Beach at
the old hospital were mostly elderly people
who had known Edgar Cayce when he had been alive.
He died in 1946.
So Gladys Davis Turner, Gladys Davis, as she's
usually known, who was Edgar Cayce's lifelong
secretary and who continued the work after he died.
And Hugh Lynn Cayce, his eldest son, I got to be very friendly with both of them.
And I interviewed all of these people who had known him and who said, no, no, he was
completely legit.
I mean, this was not some kind of scam.
And so I interviewed...
I don't believe anyone has ever questioned his sincerity.
Yes, well, you know, I did.
And I wanted to know why he went into trance.
Anyway, I got really interested in this.
I had never encountered anything like that.
So I set out to read all the readings.
And after about two years of doing that, literally
12 hours a day, sitting in the library, I
thought, well, I need to read the parapsychological
literature to understand how this fits into
this other material, the scholarly research.
And so I started reading all of the parapsychological literature.
And everything that the ARE had and everything
Old Dominion University had and everything
William & Mary had, because those were close enough to me that I could go there.
All good libraries.
All good libraries.
And I could go there and...
So you completely, at a young age, immersed yourself in all of this literature.
That was essentially the beginning of your career.
Yes.
And as a result of that, by the time I became
an experimentalist in 1968, I didn't...
And I think this has really a critical part of my career, is I didn't come at this from
the, is this stuff real?
I was already convinced that there was a legitimate phenomena here.
Just because you were familiar with the literature.
Because I was familiar both with the academic
literature, I mean, I literally read all of
the journals, the books, people that are forgotten now.
This is an important point because I didn't say by virtue of introducing you that you
have probably done more successful applied-sci
projects, especially in archeology, than
any other person who has ever lived.
Yeah, that's probably true, actually.
And it's because I began from the perspective...
I started from an anthropological point of view.
My issue was not, is it real?
My issue was, can you do anything with it?
And how does it work?
That's what I cared about.
So my experimental interests from the very beginning were not proving that what I then
called distant viewing, this is 1968, was real.
I knew that it was real because Gladys had
meticulously documented hundreds and hundreds,
thousands of cases where Casey had said things,
which today we would call outbound remote
viewing, that proved to be exactly accurate.
And there's thousands of these examples.
And so I had read all these things and I had
seen the documentation that they were correct.
So here's a man who's sitting either in Hopkinsville,
Kentucky, or in Virginia Beach, Virginia,
and he's talking about people.
And in some cases, for instance, in one particular
case that I remember, he gave a reading in
a dialect of Italian.
He didn't speak Italian.
He had an eighth grade education, post-Civil
War, rural southern education, and he's giving
this reading in not just Italian, but a dialect of Italian.
And they couldn't understand it, and they had to go out.
And Hugh Lynn went out and found a fruit vendor who came from...
It was Genovese, I think, and who could translate it.
It was for a woman in Italy.
And he gave the reading in the dialect of her region.
So there were these kinds of cases, there were stories where he would say, go to this
drug store and on the third shelf, in the back of the shelf, you'll find this bottle
and it's got this particular label.
And they would notify the pharmacist and he
would say, or he said, I don't have anything
like that.
And they said, well, go back and look.
And then he came back on the phone and said,
well, I don't know where this came from, but
that was exactly right.
There's this bottle, smoke oil, that the company
doesn't exist anymore, and it must have been
back there for years, but it was exactly where he said it was.
So that kind of thing.
Now, I know you also found examples where he was inaccurate.
Oh, yes.
Absolutely.
And that was...
Not like 100%.
No.
Of course not.
Yeah.
What that taught me, I learned a lot from studying the Casey material and also from
studying it in the context of the academic
parapsychological stuff because I realized...
Casey says very explicitly, and this of course
is true, that the questioner is as much a
player as the person who is being the remote viewer.
That the attitudes and expectations of the experimenter have an effect on the outcome
of the experiment.
In other words, it's a system.
All the people involved in the system are contributing to it in one way or another.
Yes, exactly.
So the psychic functioning, when it occurs, it's like a social phenomenon.
Yes.
I actually think of it as a bio-circuit.
That there is a linkage that occurs at the non-local level in which we bring to it our
attitudes, our expectations, and our intentions.
And so by reading the Casey readings and these
documents, I had come to understand about
this...
I mean, he says it explicitly that the attitudes
and expectations of the questioner make a
difference.
And there are two major areas where I think that Casey material just doesn't hold up.
One is his Egyptian history, and the other is Atlantis.
And I say that as one of the people who wrote
the first articles in modern times about Atlantis
because I was part of what became known as the Marine Archaeological Research Society
that was founded by Colonel Sanders of Kentucky Fried Chicken fame.
And when her son, who was a pilot, was flying
over Bimini, where Casey places Atlantis,
and saw a building under the water.
And we then went out and found the building,
and the media thought it was an Atlantean
temple.
It turns out it's a turtle pen.
And then we found the Bimini Road.
And Peter Tompkins, who wrote Secret Life Appliance and a lot of other things, Peter
and I got the U.S. Coast and Geodetic Survey Laboratories to...
We took them a part of the road and had them analyze it.
It's normal beach rock.
It just looks like it's paving, but there's just...
So...
A red herring all the way.
Right.
Yes.
And so I thought, well, why is he wrong about these two areas?
And then I went back into the...
Because of the careful documentation, I went
back into who had actually asked these questions.
And these were people who were passionately committed.
They had what you would call a cherished outcome.
Yes, they had a cherished outcome, and they were true believers.
And I realized at that point, and have now demonstrated this experimentally, that in
the non-local domain, a thing which is deeply
believed by people is, in fact, as real as
an actual thing.
That's the archetypal idea.
We know from, for instance, in remote viewing
research, that if I were to give you an experiment
in which one of the figures was your grandmother,
that even though you don't know what the target...
It's in a sealed thing, or it hasn't even been selected yet, but your grandmother's
part of the target set, that there is a significant
probability that you will displace and describe
your grandmother.
You'll be drawn to that part.
I'll be drawn to it, yeah.
Because things which are strongly held and
believed have a reality in the non-local domain
that is actually equivalent to the actual information.
It's sort of like taking a steaming tea kettle into a London fog.
It's pretty hard to tell which is the tea
kettle steam and which is the fog, and I think
that's what happens.
Sure.
Psychic work is not easy.
No, it's not easy.
Once you get past the idea that, can it be real,
and you start looking at it as a phenomena,
I saw it as an engineering problem.
I got into experimental work.
In 1968, in my back garden, I went to a ship
chandler and bought a yellow line, and I laid
out a grid of 144 foot square, 12 by 12 grid, and I photocopied the grid.
Each week, I would go, and I got a post hole
digger, and I would dig a hole, and I started
with little film canisters, and then I got to court...
You were burying objects in the garden, mapped
out by the grid, and then you'd show people
a photocopy and ask them to find the object and describe it.
That's right.
So, from my point of view, anybody that was
interested, I was interested to see how broadly
this skill was distributed, and I became clear
that it's distributed like any human skill,
whether it's violin playing, or tennis playing, or golfing.
There's a few people that are really, really good at it.
There's a few people that are really, really
bad at it, but most of us fall somewhere in
the middle.
And that's what taught me that.
So each week, for about...
This is like your first experiment.
These were my first experiments.
For about a year, every week, so that's like
52 of them, I would bury in one of the grids,
and the reason 144 was, you know, one in 20,
and so, okay, one in 144, and I would ask
people...
You could do a statistical analysis.
Exactly.
And I would give them a sheet of this grid on a piece of paper, and I would say, first
of all, would you please go over this grid?
And sometimes there was nothing there, sometimes
there were things there, and I would say,
if you believe the target that I would like you to discover is in this grid, would you
please mark the grid that you think it's at?
And if you think it's there, would you please describe for me what it would be?
And it would be things like Barbie dolls in the jar, or scissors, or an ink blotter,
or an orange, and so all kinds of things,
because I was trying to see were some things
easier to see than other things, and could some people do...
And what I discovered was a small percentage
of people, if I were guessing, I would say,
about 12% were pretty good at it, and could do it.
And there was another small little group, a little smaller, who just could never do
it, never seemed to be able to give themselves
permission to do it, and I got interested
in why that was true.
So when I began to do experimentation, my
interest, as I say, was not, is it real, but...
You never doubted it was real, because you had immersed yourself for five years in the
literature itself.
Before I did anything.
And that's something that most researchers, I have to say, don't do.
Most researchers are not as familiar with the literature, let alone having read every
single Edgar Cayce reading.
Well every reading, and essentially everything
that had been published in parapsychology.
I mean, I started with the beginning of Jasper, and the beginning of the JP, and...
The Journal of the American Society for Psychical
Research, and the Journal of Parapsychology.
And the Society for Psychical Research in London.
The Proceedings that go back to 1882.
Yeah.
And you know, they were in the library, nobody
read them, I'd get these old crumbly journals
out, this was when they were still, you know,
pre-computers, and that's what I did, twelve
hours a day.
So the number one lesson, if I were a young person interested in going into the field,
I would say the lesson that you could offer
is immerse themselves in the literature first
and foremost.
Yes.
Stephen, our time is up.
Oh.
Okay.
It goes quickly when you're having fun.
This has been a delight.
I know we're going to have a number of other
interesting conversations on related topics.
Thank you so much for being with me.
My pleasure.
And thank you for being with us.
